Title: Specs and Speed
Paragraph: Most of our clients have a general idea of what their requirements are for their software. In some cases, they have a very clear idea of what they want. However, when executing a project, hundreds if not thousands of details need to be defined. It is close to impossible for a non-professional to do so upfront, as one will tend to overlook most of the questions. But even for a professional, it is very difficult to produce a coherent spec sheet upfront: we noticed that almost all the spec sheets we receive have numerous internal contradictions or omissions, making it impossible to actually execute the project without minor or sometimes even major revisions. In the next installment of 4i Insights, we will describe some tools to improve the process of writing specs. At the moment, please remember this: the better the specs, the faster a project can be executed. Better specs=faster speed!

Title: Prototyping
Paragraph: Creating a prototype is a great tool for writing good specs, as it creates a visual and tactile interface that makes the product self-explanatory. In addition, we have often experienced that clients’ ideas on what their software is supposed to achieve are well-aligned, while design is more subjective, and can create disagreements. It is best for such disagreements to be resolved at the start of the project, rather than at the end. Prototyping is a great way to make sure that the discussions are efficient, and it forces the discussion on many aspects of the specs which one might not think about without a prototype. It is much cheaper and less time consuming to fiddle around on a prototype, rather than on a fully developed software product with an integrated and often complex backend. Some online tools allow for wireframing as well as fully fledged design. The tools we use most are Zeplin, InVision, Sketch, and Photoshop. All have their respective advantages and drawbacks, and we use them for different scenarios . Some can be integrated with each other to some extent. Are you interested in explaining in more detail which tool we use in which case, and why? If so, please let us know, and we will address it in a future newsletter. In the next issue of Insights, we will address our favourite collaboration tools for software development. Please stay tuned!

Title: Notes on planning your software resources
Paragraph: Software is always-changing and always under development. Microsoft word for instance has had a new release every 2-3 years since its inception in 1984, with multiple bug fixes in-between. So, you need a good resource plan to match your development roadmap. How to do that? – First and foremost, make sure that someone inside or outside of your company knows how the various parts of the software work together. You want your resources to spend a majority of their time improving your software, and not just on understanding what their predecessor(s) have done. Depending on the technology used and the development process, handing over software to new developers can be time-consuming. – Secondly, be sure to have a good plan for your development needs, and a good bug reporting system. There are many bug report systems out there for the different needs companies may have, and we have used many of them – let us know if you would like us to point you in the right direction. – Lastly: discuss the development plan and bug database with your in-house or outsourced development team. Title: A brief history of software
Paragraph: Let’s start recapitulate the history of software: -  There are many precursors to modern software. Some concepts such as the abacus (possibly as early as 5,000 years ago) are very ancient, but the first algorithm was devised in the 19th century by Charles Babbage / Ada Lovelace. However this was purely theoretical. -  In 1935 Alan Turing wrote the first theory of software, and the first electronic computer, the ENIAC, came into existence in 1946, and was used to calculate artillery firing tables for the US army. -  From 1948 to 1979, various binary codes were developed to perform calculations, and the programming languages Fortran, COBOL and BASIC were developed. The Apollo mission was the first endeavor that depended on software for practical and complex tasks. -  From the 1960’s onwards, minicomputers started to be sold. They were essentially miniaturized mainframes, and came with pre-installed software. Most of the software was stored on cassette tapes and cartridges. -  From the 1980’s to early 2000’s, PC’s came into wider use, with the industry dominated first by Apple and then IBM.   In Taiwan, the computer industry started in 1976, driven by the local production prowess, and affinity to technology. The expertise grew fast, with Taiwan quickly becoming a critical element in the international supply chains. The 1980’s and 90’s saw the emergence of Taiwan’s semiconductors industry, which necessitated advanced researchers to develop the coming generations of microchips. The emergence of Taiwan’s large-scale software industry started in the 1990’s but really took off around 2010, which is incidentally the year in which 4i DPS was founded. Taiwan is now such a critical element of the semiconductors industry that the New York Times recently called it “pound for pound the most important place in the world”. It has both hardware and software capabilities that are unmatched by any other territory that small. With this, we wish you a very successful year of the Ox! Title: Can technology make elections more transparent?
Paragraph:
Election Technology

Elections are at the core of democracy, and having had the opportunity to work on an international election project in early 2020, here are some insights into the technological landscape.

 

Voting technology

 

Typically each territory has its own laws governing election equipment, and the voting equipment has to be customized to those laws. The equipment can have various functionalities, such as counting ballots, checking ID’s and biometrical data, issuing voting receipts, etc. In some territories, the customization has to take place on short notice, since the selection of the supplier happens shortly before the election takes place. Therefore, some large vendors of voting equipment essentially consist of teams of engineers with knowledge of voting technology, and production facilities for voting equipment; and each election is a project, in which the modules are assembled and customized to fit the project.

Elections could become virtual events in the future
 

In the future, as we start to increasingly use our digital persona, elections could become purely virtual events. After all, some territories already encourage digital tax filing, payments, digital signatures etc. – it is not a big step to imagine some territories advocating purely digital elections, possibly in combination with limited in-person voting opportunities.

Digital voting advantages

If it is done properly, digital voting has big advantages: for instance, voters can be given sole access to their (encrypted) voting record on the voting database, thus being able to verify if their vote has been counted.

The voter database can be audited easily: it would contain the information about who voted, while the vote itself is only accessible by the voter for verification purposes.

Blockchain Decentralisation

The Blockchain’s decentralized nature lends itself as a technology for elections, although various approaches are possible, with or without a blockchain component. Several large corporations, for instance, Microsoft, have developed their own approaches; at the moment the largest impediment to the introduction appears to be not technology, but the will of the political system to go ahead.   As a Taiwan-Swiss company, we are particularly interested in the subject of voting and keep abreast of the developments in this field.

Title: Make sure that you have a sound software maintenance plan
Paragraph: Software maintenance Software is not static; it works on a server environment, communicates with other pieces of software, and is subject to new requirements from its users or legislators. In addition, some of your software’s components may themselves undergo updates, or may no longer be supported. Please make sure that you have a person responsible for maintaining your software at all times. How do you find / appoint that person or company? 1) One efficient way is to get the entity which developed your software, to maintain it. The average app contains more than 50,000 lines of code, and it takes time for a new entity to understand how it all fits together! However, in the medium term, you will probably need to appoint a new entity, due to personnel, availability or other changes. 2) If a new entity is to maintain your software, please plan ahead, as it could take up to a month or more for a new person to understand the code base and be able to make new commits on it. 3) Make sure to have a thorough documentation of your software! 4) Be careful if the entity assigned to maintain your software proposes to redevelop it from scratch instead: redevelopments tend to take longer than anticipated, plus you may run into the same problem again later, if a new entity has to take over. Refactoring could be a better option; we will write more about this in a future newsletter. Please contact us if you want us to give you a software maintenance proposal.

Title: Work in the age of Corona
Paragraph:
In the age of Corona, remote work has become increasingly popular, and even a necessity.
Most people assume that since programming is done in front of a computer, and Engineers aren’t always the most communicative people anyway :), development is quasi predestined for remote work.
However, working in an office does have advantages:
-  It’s convenient for employees to have a workstation in the office, without having to reserve space at home for their work.
-  It’s convenient for project managers to be able to “gather their troops” every morning for the daily standup meeting, without having to deal with communication issues (yes, not everyone has a perfect connection 24/7 in their house).
-  It’s convenient for all of us to visually see who is here and who isn’t, without having to click into a communication software.
-  It’s convenient for everyone to be able to discuss any issue with their colleague without delay (engineers don’t constantly have their communication tools in front of them) – the ability to discuss an issue “here and now” can end up in efficiency savings.
“Convenience” here doesn’t just mean “comfort”: convenience can result in lower bug rates, faster development time, and better resources alignment.
Our conclusion: we find a mix of in-office work and work from home ideal. Sometimes it is best for engineers to work from home for a day, so they aren’t disturbed by their colleagues, and can focus on solving some very hairy issues. But much of the time, it’s still more efficient to work from the office (as long as that is possible). This will also apply to your outsourced team with us.

Title: Government surveillance in times of COVID
Paragraph:
Government surveillance in times of COVID

During the COVID crisis, a lot has been said about the invasion of privacy and imposing lockdowns in many countries around the world. It is a real problem if the people who control Governments have the ability to check if their laws are enforced at a granular and individual level, so the concern is justified. It is important to separate practical and theoretical discussions. My basic framework is that “If a technology exists and is useful, someone somewhere will definitely use it. So you should spend time thinking about what the consequences will be, and how you want to position yourself considering the new tech, as opposed to wondering about theoretical issues” For instance, when the steam engine was invented, people had a lot of thoughts about this new tech. Some ignored it, some wished that it would disappear. Others took advantage of it. The same happened with electric lights, telephones, smartphones, E-mail, etc. The same has been happening with your data for the past 10+ years, including medical and spending patterns. So the question is: how do we position ourselves to take advantage of this fact, and how do we avoid all becoming slaves to Governments worldwide? My take is that data transparency works both ways: Governments have a lot more data about their citizens than before. But the citizens also have a lot more data about their Governments than before. In democracies, it is our duty, as citizens, to look at this data and be informed about what our Governments do. If we do that effectively, and our Governments are therefore held accountable, this restricts their ability to use our own information against us. So everyone wins: Governments win because they are accountable for their actions, and citizens win because by checking how their data is used, they can assure it is not used against them in a nefarious way. And society progresses and improves. Once again, technology helps us in our daily lives.

Title: Salesforce CRM - Features & Customer Success Story
